data.title: Atom no longer remembers previous session
data.body:
Using 0.209.0 on Windows 7 Pro 64-bit, Atom (even in safe mode) will no longer open a new first-and-only window with the session state (open folder and open files) from the previous last-to-be-closed Atom window.
#6917 seems similar, but that was fixed. I guess this might be a regression, unless it was a deliberate choice. I found no issue or changelog or release notes that mentioned it.

I believe 0.208.0 restored the previous session, and the last version in which the previous session wasn't restored was some time ago, maybe around 0.197.0 or so but not sure. Even then, File / Exit seemed to allow session restoring, while the window's close button did not. Now, neither seem to allow the previous session to be restored. (File / Close Window doesn't currently work either, but I hadn't checked it closely in previous versions.)

data.title: After "Save As", status bar filename has unsaved asterisk until next save
data.body:
Using 0.209.0 on Windows 7 Pro 64-bit, every time I use Save As (on plain text files, anyway), just after the operation completes the new file's name in the statusbar has the "unsaved asterisk" suffixed:

![atom-save-asterisk-after-saveas](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3069355/8138724/085dbb74-1113-11e5-86b4-cc6f902f8a8f.PNG)

The asterisk disappears after I make further modifications to the buffer and save the file.

data.title: High CPU usage when updating multiple packages.
data.body:
Atom takes 40% CPU when updating multiple packages.
Doing it one by one do not increase CPU usage but when clicking multiple updates at once , atom raise to 40% cpu and never finishes.

Tested at : 
atom version v0.209.0-33accdf
Linux 64bit.

data.title: Problem with killing children processes
data.body:
Hi there. I seem to be running into a problem using the atom-script editor, you can see it here: rgbkrk/atom-script#453

Basically, atom-script runs go, which in turn starts up a server. Killing the process with a control-c kills off the child process, but not the child of the child. 

```
13:53|~/go/src/github.com/davewv31/helloworld/helloworld% ps ax | grep helloworld
84187   ??  S      0:00.22 go run /Users/dave/go/src/github.com/davewv31/helloworld/helloworld/helloworld.go
84218   ??  S      0:00.22 /var/folders/2v/53vdc3j9187f6zj1ljjfc10h0000gn/T/go-build234219847/command-line-arguments/_obj/exe/helloworld
```

After control-c in atom:

```
13:53|~/go/src/github.com/davewv31/helloworld/helloworld% ps ax | grep helloworld
84218   ??  S      0:00.22 /var/folders/2v/53vdc3j9187f6zj1ljjfc10h0000gn/T/go-build234219847/command-line-arguments/_obj/exe/helloworld
```

In buffered-process.coffee, the windows and non-windows terminations seem to be different. Windows seems to kill children of children, non-windows seems to just kill the child. 

```
  killProcess: ->
    @process?.kill()
    @process = null
```

So I guess what this comes down to is what should the expected behavior of BufferedProcess.kill be? It does just wrap child_process, but doesn't allow a full process group kill (which I want) or a signal type to be sent(which I'm not sure would work). 

Thanks!

data.title: Include minimap
data.body: Has anyone ever considered including the [Minimap](https://atom.io/packages/minimap) package in the core Atom build? It has over 350,000 downloads, it seems like almost everyone is using it and I think it should be included out of the box.

data.title: Javascript files saved as binary
data.body:
Hello,

Yesterday I had shut down my laptop after working on some javascript files. When I started it up this morning 3 of those files were in a binary format. I have no idea what had happened as the only thing I would have done last night was save them and alt+f4 atom.

I'm on: 
Ubuntu 14.04 x86-64
3.18.4-031804-generic
atom io version 0.208.0

Not too sure what logs might help to figure this out. If anyone has recommendations for what to do that be fantastic. Even better if you have a suggestion for how I might be able to get my work back :(

data.title: Use latest npm in build
data.body:
This bumps npm to the latest version (2.11.2) - part of [an effort to update dependencies.](https://david-dm.org/atom/atom) Let's see if this goes green! :traffic_light: 

Fixes https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8045

data.title: In semi-transparent themes , tilerendering Colors the Tile area and Lines area , differently from the atom-editor.
data.body:
In transparent themes , tile rendering applies colors differently. Observable in my theme :

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/419606/8125580/dcb46c58-110c-11e5-9761-8a2dc2946b14.png)

If it is not a bug , what would be recommended way for theme developers to theme those tiles ?

data.title: `atom` command not opening current folder
data.body:
I had originally installed atom via `brew cask install` and the `atom` command was working fine. Then, for reasons, I uninstalled the cask version and installed atom from atom.io. Ever since, despite performing "Install Shell Commands" and making sure the symlinks are correct, the `atom` command fails to load the current folder. It's highly likely this is isolated to my installation only, but I'm having a hard time figuring out where things go wrong.

I have tried:
- Removing ~/.atom entirely
- Exporting a nearly uncustomized `$PATH` before launching atom
- Atom -> Install Shell Commands (and manually checking the symlinks after)
- Launching from various folders, just in case there was something weird in the pathname

So far nothing has worked.

Atom seems to be getting the `--executed-from` argument just fine and with a correct value. For example, if I launch atom in /tmp, I can see the following command with `ps aux | grep -i atom`:

```
/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/MacOS/Atom --executed-from=/tmp --pid=77617 --path-environment=/Users/redacted/.bin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin
```

The launched editor just shows a blank untitled document, does not open the tree view, and Cmd+P says that the project is empty. The `--pid` doesn't point to any existing process but then again I don't really know what it's for anyway.

File -> Open does work.

Any ideas? I'm on 0.209.0 currently but the issue has persisted for a month or so.

Here's the path to the atom script in case it helps:

```
âžœ  /tmp  readlink /usr/local/bin/atom
/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app/atom.sh
```

data.title: Auto indent keybinding not working after 0.208.0
data.body:
I had keymap defined for auto indent but it stopped working after 0.208.0. There was some deprecation with `editor` classes, tried to fix it but still doesn't work. I verified with keybinding resolver that it triggers the rule so that shouldn't be the problem but instead the problem seems to be with the command it's trying to run. Both outdent and indent work properly.

My keymap looks like this:

```
'.atom-workspace .atom-text-editor:not(.mini)':
  'ctrl-alt-left': 'atom-editor:auto-indent'
  'ctrl-alt-8': 'atom-editor:outdent-selected-rows'
  'ctrl-alt-9': 'atom-editor:indent'
```

data.title: Do not include redundant closing quote when valid quote already exists on same line
data.body:
See the following example:

![ex1](https://www.dropbox.com/s/8ciiou7liutx4mo/quote%20replacement.gif?dl=1)

When a valid matching closing quote already exists on the same line, Atom should not auto include a redundant closing quote.

data.title: Handle native cut command in render process too
data.body:
I imagine the cut command was missed when this was originally done in https://github.com/atom/atom/commit/bb1bcc233ae37f6e72f3172db30908885c768919 ?

I verified it working manually by [re-building atom](https://github.com/atom/atom#building) and adding an input element with the `native-key-bindings` class through the developer console, e.g.

``` js
i=document.createElement('input'); i.classList.add('native-key-bindings'); i.type="text"; i.tabIndex="-1"; document.body.appendChild(i); i.style.position="absolute"; i.style.zIndex=3; i.style.bottom=0; i.style.border="5px solid red"; i;
```

and verifying that the cut now works with this change.

data.title: Pressing alt destroys unsaved changes and entire tabs and undo buffer
data.body:
Atom 0.208.0 on Linux Mint 17.1 Cinnamon
1. Go to a directory in the shell.
2. Launch atom from the shell.
3. Open a file.
4. Go down a couple screens in the file and type some rubbish without saving.
5. Press alt.
6. Observe that the menu is now visible, the unsaved changes in the file are destroyed, the undo buffer is cleared, and the cursor position resets to the first line in the file.

The above steps on an unsaved tab will actually destroy its contents and close it.

Screenshots (sorry, upload doesn't seem to be working for me today):
- Enter some rubbish in the buffer: https://img.bi/#/QvT4bXP!exmmkclbatacdtDfbcfaECGqJaWnnajdWyrzicur
- Tap alt and see the menu: https://img.bi/#/nbZT9ww!cyeabHOkhxqCozesEnozCaQdgpkwBsziDejKbbBw

I did not observe any errors in the dev console.

data.title: Add missing docs for GitRepository
data.body: Add argument and return type docs to fill in the documentation site.

data.title: Un-styled scrollbars appear after waking from sleep if external mouse is plugged in
data.body:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Ensure that no external mouse is plugged in
2. Put computer to sleep
3. Plug in external mouse (preferably a non-Apple mouse with a scroll wheel)
4. Wake computer from sleep
5. Atom will have un-styled scrollbars
- OS X 10.10.3
  - System Preferences > General > Show scroll bars > Automatically based on mouse or trackpad
- Atom 0.209.0 (but I've noticed this for many versions now)

Can anyone else reproduce this? (@atom/feedback?)

data.title: tabs@0.81.0
data.body: This adds VCS coloring for tabs. (Thanks @acontreras89!)

data.title: Avoid saving state when closing windows due to auto-update
data.body:
This also fixes some cases where the window state would incorrectly be saved in the middle of exiting.
- [x] Avoid incorrectly saving state as windows are closed while restarting to install an update.
- [x] Make sure that `quitting` state doesn't incorrectly persist if quit is cancelled due to unsaved buffers.

Fixes #7156
Fixes #7214

data.title: Add Slack readme badge
data.body:
Now that we've had Slack going for awhile, let's advertise it on the Readme!

/cc @thedaniel

data.title: Feature Request: "Match Quotes" option in finder
data.body:
Similar to "Match Case" (and turned off by default).

When disabled, typing `'` or `"` in the finder query would essentially match the regexp `['"]`.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/185923/8115047/124b56c4-1036-11e5-943b-f42f41edb311.png)

data.title: 0.209.0 doesn't save session
data.body:
Atom 0.209.0 doesn't save open files and folders on exit (0.208.0 made this). After restart, there is only empty "untitled" file.
Here's my config:

``` cson
"*":
  "exception-reporting":
    userId: "480b20de-e736-263e-a240-4205e8c90e87"
  welcome:
    showOnStartup: false
  core:
    themes: [
      "one-dark-ui"
      "solarized-dark-syntax"
    ]
  editor:
    fontFamily: "'M+ 1mn regular'"
    invisibles: {}
  minimap:
    plugins:
      "git-diff": true
      bookmarks: true
      selection: true
      "color-highlight": true
      "find-and-replace": true
  "atom-beautify":
    _analyticsUserId: "13adc827-7ceb-4c02-bdb7-7a6d1b173567"
    c_configPath: "/usr/share/uncrustify/defaults.cfg"
    cpp_configPath: "/usr/share/uncrustify/defaults.cfg"
    cs_configPath: "/usr/share/uncrustify/defaults.cfg"
    objectivec_configPath: "/usr/share/uncrustify/defaults.cfg"
    java_configPath: "/usr/share/uncrustify/defaults.cfg"
  tabs:
    usePreviewTabs: true
  linter: {}
  "git-plus":
    wordDiff: false
  "merge-conflicts": {}
  "linter-clang":
    clangDefaultCFlags: "-Wall -Wextra -std=c99"
    clangDefaultCppFlags: "-Wall -Wextra -std=c++11"
  "atom-color-highlight": {}
  "autocomplete-clang": {}
  "open-recent": {}
```

0.209.0 built from sources.

data.title: Syntax mode is not available from command palette
data.body:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Press Ctrl-Shift-P.
2. Type "syntax javascript".
3. No matches found.

Expected result:

The syntax mode menu should be reachable from the command palette.

A similar issue exists with the encoding menu.

data.title: Close All is not available from the command palette
data.body:
Steps to reproduce
1. Press Ctrl-Shift-P.
2. Type "close all".
3. No matches found.

Expected result.

The command for close all should be shown. I know there is such a command because I can get to it by right clicking on a tab.

data.title: Mini atom-text-editor doesn't handle horizontal overflow unless a space is used
data.body:
Hereâ€™s an illustration of the issue:

![texteditor mini horizontal overflow](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/517889/8112251/a813a3d4-1034-11e5-97eb-392c4c7bdad9.gif)

Basically, the text youâ€™re typing becomes invisible until you type a space. This is particularly problematic if the mini TextEditor is being used for something like a long URL, which you wouldnâ€™t expect to have spaces.

Using Atom v0.208.0 on Mac OS 10.10.3

data.title: Creating accelerator keys in package
data.body:
I notice that the ctrl f find and replace window does not have accelerator keys. Looking at the docu I am only seeing accelerator keys on Menu items.

If I am going to create a similar package as this would it be able to show accelerator keys? Is there a docu showing how this is done?

data.title: Saving a file takes too long.
data.body:
When editing a file, saving sometimes takes about 2sec (not actually measured, just a feeling). This leads to workflow problems for me, because doing the following commands sometimes takes less than the time that atom needs for saving the file:
- Edit a source file
- Save it
- Switch to terminal
- Run something that uses the file
- BOOM!

I don't know too much about the internals of atom, but it looks like the document needs to be stripped of all its html markup before being saved, which takes time of course. Maybe, a plain text copy of the content could be stored in memory, which is used for quickly saving the content.
